metadata.titleEn: Multi-scale surface flux and meteorological elements observation dataset in the Hai River Basin (Huailai station-eddy covariance system-10m tower, 2019)
metadata.description:
This dataset contains the flux measurements from the Huailai station eddy covariance system (EC) from January 1 to December 3 in 2019. The site (115.7880° E, 40.3491° N) was located in the maize surface, near Donghuayuan town of Huailai city in Hebei Province. The elevation is 480 m. The EC was installed at a height of 5 m, and the sampling rate was 10 Hz. The sonic anemometer faced north, and the separation distance between the sonic anemometer and the CO2/H2O gas analyzer (CSAT3&Li7500A) was 0.15 m.
The raw data acquired at 10 Hz were processed using the Eddypro post-processing software, including the spike detection, lag correction of H2O/CO2 relative to the vertical wind component, sonic virtual temperature correction, coordinate rotation (2-D rotation), corrections for density fluctuation (Webb-Pearman-Leuning correction), and frequency response correction. The EC data were subsequently averaged over 30 min periods. The observation data quality was divided into three classes according to the quality assessment method of stationarity (Δst) and the integral turbulent characteristics test (ITC): class 1 (level 0: Δst<30 and ITC<30), class 2 (level 1: Δst<100 and ITC<100), and class 3 (level 2: Δst>100 and ITC>100), which represent high-, medium-, and low-quality data, respectively. In addition to the above processing steps, the half-hourly flux data were screened in a four-step procedure: (1) data from periods of sensor malfunction were rejected; (2) data collected before or after 1 h of precipitation were rejected; (3) incomplete 30 min data were rejected when the missing data constituted more than 10% of the 30 min raw record; and (4) data were rejected at night when the friction velocity (u*) was less than 0.1 m/s. There were 48 records per day, and the missing data were replaced with -6999. 
The released data contained the following variables: data/time, wind direction (Wdir, °), wind speed (Wnd, m/s), the standard deviation of the lateral wind (Std_Uy, m/s), virtual temperature (Tv, ℃), H2O mass density (H2O, g/m3), CO2 mass density (CO2, mg/m3), friction velocity (ustar, m/s), stability (z/L), sensible heat flux (Hs, W/m2), latent heat flux (LE, W/m2), carbon dioxide flux (Fc, mg/ (m2s)), quality assessment of the sensible heat flux (QA_Hs), quality assessment of the latent heat flux (QA_LE), and quality assessment of the carbon flux (QA_Fc). In this dataset, the time of 0:30 corresponds to the average data for the period between 0:00 and 0:30; the data were stored in *.xls format. Detailed information can be found in the suggested references.
For more information, please refer to Guo et al. (2020) (for sites information), Liu et al. (2013) for data processing) in the Citation section.

background: Aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) is a key factor in surface flux estimations with remote sensing algorithms and/or land surface models. Originally, z0m is defined as the height where the wind speed, given by the extrapolation of the logarithmic wind profile, becomes zero. According to numerous observations, the variation range of z0m over different surfaces is large, from an order of 1.0 m over urban areas and mountainous areas, to an order of 0.1 mm or even 0.01 mm over smooth water body surfaces, ice and snow surfaces. The traditional way to calculate z0m is based on the Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory, using wind profile measurements. In practical applications, especially for remote sensing models and land surface models, it is difficult to obtain z0m for a local or regional scale based only on station observations. Former researchers have proposed some parameterizations between the aerodynamic roughness length and the land surface properties [e.g., vegetation height, leaf area index (LAI), etc.], since wind turbulence is controlled by the structure and spacing of roughness elements (plants and other obstacles) on the land surface, and z0m describes the roughness characteristics of a surface.
research objective: Based on the data of the Xiaotangshan Experiment (Changping District of Beijing, China), which was conducted in 2002, 2004, and 2005 respectively, the objectives of this paper are: (1) to calculate z0m over different surfaces and analyze the directional characteristics of z0m over heterogeneous surfaces using an analytical footprint model; (2) to relate the estimated z0m over heterogeneous surfaces to roughness element characteristic factors, and present a heuristic parameterization of z0m as a reference for model parameterizations.
challenges: More data is needed for further discussions.
methods: This paper calculates z0m over several land surfaces, with 3 years of experimental data from Xiaotangshan. Individual z0m over each surface component (patch) is calculated firstly with the characteristic parameters of the roughness elements (vegetation height, leaf area index, etc.), then z0m over the whole experimental field is aggregated, using the footprint weighting method.
dataset: This experiment was carried out at the Xiaotangshan Experimental Station for Precision Agriculture (40°10′41′′N, 116°26′52′′E, 35 m above sea level) in Beijing. The observation period in 2002 was from 26 March to 23 April and the land cover was bare soil. In 2004, the experiment was carried out from 30 May to 7 July. In the southern sub-plot field, the land cover was bare soil between 30 May and 11 June, while the maize plants started emerging around 12 June. In 2005, the experiment was from 1 May to 10 June and the experimental layout was almost the same as that in 2004.
findings: The results show that z0m is direction-dependent, mainly due to the heterogeneity of the size and spatial distribution of the roughness elements inside the source area along different wind directions.

background: Sensible and latent heat fluxes are important indicators reflecting the intensity of heat and water vapor exchange between the land and atmosphere, influencing the energy balance between them, providing material, dynamic, and thermal sources for weather systems of different scales, and affecting the water cycle process between the land and atmosphere. Currently, there are many traditional methods for observing surface fluxes, such as the Eddy-Covariance system (EC), Bowen ratio-energy balance system, and aerodynamic methods. Among these, the Eddy-Covariance system is internationally recognized as the most reliable method for observing surface fluxes; however, its observation scale is relatively small, with spatial representativeness only in the range of tens to hundreds of meters. The Large Aperture Scintillometer (LAS), compared to traditional Eddy-Covariance systems, can obtain average sensible heat fluxes at a regional scale (from hundreds of meters to several kilometers). Since the observation scale of LAS can better match the pixel scale of satellite imagery and the grid scale of numerical weather prediction and climate models, the observations from LAS can serve as ground truth for the pixel/grid scale of remote sensing estimation models, numerical weather prediction models, and climate models, thereby optimizing and validating these models. The observation principle of LAS is based on the Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory (MOST), which, combined with the observed atmospheric refractive index structure parameter C2n and related meteorological data, utilizes the stability universal function fT related to the temperature structure parameter C2T to obtain the regional average sensible heat flux at the surface.
research objective: Using the LAS-related data from Guantao Station (January to December 2009) and Arou Station (January to June and October to November), the applicability of the Monin-Obukhov similarity theory (MOST) in LAS observations was analyzed, and a quantitative assessment method for the applicability of MOST was explored.
challenges: Due to the influence of underlying surface cover types, flatness, water-heat conditions, and weather conditions, it is difficult to achieve the ideal assumption of uniformity in practice. Currently, domestic research on atmospheric similarity theory mainly focuses on the similarity relationships of wind, temperature profiles, and turbulence variance. However, there is relatively little research on the similarity between temperature structure parameters and turbulence characteristics in scintillation methods.
methods: Before analyzing the applicability of the MOST theory to LAS data, preliminary processing of EC and LAS data is conducted. LAS, EC, and AWS data from the Guantao station for the year 2009 (January to December) and from the Aru station (January to June and October to November) are selected.
dataset:
Guantao Station (36°30′54″N, 115°07′39″E) is located in Hezhai Village, Guantao County, Hebei Province. Its observation site and surrounding underlying surface consist of farmland, including winter wheat, corn, and cotton, with winter wheat and corn being rotated. The growth period for winter wheat is from October to June of the following year, while corn grows from June to October, and cotton grows from May to October, representing a typical farmland underlying surface of the North China Plain. In the LAS source area, winter wheat (corn) accounts for about 45% of the area, while cotton accounts for about 47%. 

Arou Station (38°02′40″N, 100°27′53″E) is located in the valley area upstream of the Heihe River, where its observation site and surrounding underlying surface consist of typical alpine grassland, which is relatively flat. The vegetation in the source area can reach a height of 0.2 to 0.3 meters during the growing season.
findings: (1) Under unstable conditions, large-scale vortex motion, atmospheric turbulence development, and temperature scales can significantly affect the applicability of the MOST theory; (2) Two new methods for determining the applicability of the MOST theory have been established, namely factor analysis and temperature structure parameter methods, and it has been verified that these two judgment methods are reasonable and reliable.

background: For surface flux measurements, large aperture scintillometer (LAS) has become more and more popular in recent years. Compared with traditional observation techniques, it can measure surface fluxes on a larger scale (500 m to 10 km). At present, LAS observation is not common in China.
research objective: The daily and monthly variation of HLAS is analyzed. And the observation differences between eddy covariance system and LAS, need to be studied further combined with footprint model and energy unbalance of eddy covariance system observation.
challenges: There is much less agreement on the form which universal stability function fT should take. Further more, since the iteration process of HLAS can not be convergence when low wind speed and very stable conditions appearing at night, Wm \ - 5 is specified.
findings: Sensible heat flux (H) calculation with the LAS data of above measurements shows that the beam height of LAS and wind speed are sensitive factors for sensible heat flux measurement (HLAS), zero-plane displacement height is crucial unless the beam height is much larger than it, and Bowen ratio needs to be determined accurately over wet surface, while air temperature, air pressure and aerodynamic roughness length are not sensitive for HLAS. According to the observations mentioned above, LAS can measure surface fluxes both over homogeneous and heterogeneous surfaces.

Definition.Question: What does 'eddy covariance system' mean in the context of surface flux measurements?
Definition.Answer: The eddy covariance system is an internationally recognized and reliable method for surface flux measurements, particularly for observing small-scale fluxes typically within tens to hundreds of meters. It involves measuring the vertical turbulent fluxes of momentum, heat, and gases such as CO2 using high-frequency data collection techniques, and is considered the most reliable method for these observations.

Definition.Question: What is meant by 'aerodynamic roughness length (z0m)' in relation to surface flux estimations?
Definition.Answer: Aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) is a key factor in surface flux estimations with remote sensing algorithms and land surface models. It is defined as the height where the wind speed, extrapolated from the logarithmic wind profile, becomes zero. It varies widely over different surfaces and is influenced by the structure and spacing of roughness elements like vegetation, describing the roughness characteristics of a surface.

Definition.Question: What is the 'Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory (MOST)' and how is it applicable to surface flux measurements?
Definition.Answer: The Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory (MOST) is a theoretical framework used to relate turbulent fluxes of momentum, heat, and mass to mean meteorological variables. It is applicable to surface flux measurements as it helps in estimating regional average sensible heat fluxes using parameters like the atmospheric refractive index structure and temperature structure parameter. It is particularly used in conjunction with techniques like the large aperture scintillometer (LAS) to match the scale of satellite pixels and climate model grids.

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection methods using eddy covariance systems compare to large aperture scintillometer (LAS) systems in terms of spatial scale and application in surface flux measurements?
Comparison.Answer: Eddy covariance systems are internationally recognized as the most reliable method for surface flux observations, primarily used for small spatial scales with representation ranging from tens to a few hundred meters. In contrast, LAS can obtain regional scale averages of sensible heat flux over several hundred meters to kilometers, making it suitable for matching satellite pixel scales and model grid scales. Thus, LAS is more applicable for larger spatial scale measurements compared to eddy covariance systems.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in challenges faced when applying the Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory (MOST) in data analysis for eddy covariance compared to large aperture scintillometer systems?
Comparison.Answer: When applying MOST, both systems face challenges, but they differ in specifics. For LAS, the heterogeneity of underlying surfaces and atmospheric conditions affect the theory's applicability. The challenges include the need for accurate determination of stability functions and dealing with non-converging iterations at low wind speeds and stable conditions. Eddy covariance systems, however, primarily deal with their limited spatial representation and the influence of surface characteristics on data accuracy.

Interpretation.Question: What factors may influence the accuracy and reliability of surface flux measurements collected using eddy covariance systems, and how can these be systematically accounted for in data processing?
Interpretation.Answer: Factors such as instrument errors, environmental conditions like precipitation, and weak turbulence at night can affect the accuracy of data collected using eddy covariance systems. Systematic data processing steps include delay time correction, coordinate rotation, frequency response correction, and quality assessment based on atmospheric stability and turbulence similarity to ensure reliability.

Interpretation.Question: How do the spatial scale limitations of traditional eddy covariance systems compare to those of large aperture scintillometers, and what implications do these differences have for matching satellite pixel scales?
Interpretation.Answer: Traditional eddy covariance systems have a spatial scale limited to tens or hundreds of meters, while large aperture scintillometers can measure fluxes over larger areas ranging from hundreds of meters to kilometers. This broader scale of scintillometers allows for better alignment with satellite pixel scales, making them suitable for validating remote sensing models and numerical weather prediction models.

Interpretation.Question: In what ways do the characteristics of the land surface and surrounding environment affect the calculation of aerodynamic roughness length, and how can data from different experimental sites be integrated into a comprehensive model?
Interpretation.Answer: The aerodynamic roughness length is affected by the height and distribution of vegetation and other surface obstacles. By analyzing data from various experimental sites with different surface conditions, such as those from Xiaotangshan and other locations, researchers can develop parameterizations that relate roughness length to land surface characteristics, aiding in the creation of a comprehensive model for broader applications.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What are the causes behind the reliance on eddy covariance systems for surface flux measurements despite their limited spatial representation?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The eddy covariance system is internationally recognized as the most reliable method for observing surface fluxes because it directly measures the exchange of heat, water vapor, and gases between the land surface and the atmosphere. However, its limited spatial representation is due to its small observation scale, which only covers tens to hundreds of meters, making it challenging to represent larger, heterogeneous areas.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is it challenging to apply Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory in LAS observations over heterogeneous surfaces?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The application of Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory is challenging over heterogeneous surfaces because the assumptions of horizontal homogeneity are often violated. Factors such as surface cover type, flatness, water and heat conditions, and weather conditions can disrupt the ideal conditions required for the theory, making it difficult to accurately apply it without additional consideration of these variabilities.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the difficulty in deriving aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) over heterogeneous landscapes for remote sensing models?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The difficulty in deriving aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) over heterogeneous landscapes arises from the variability in surface characteristics such as vegetation height, leaf area index, and the spatial distribution and structure of roughness elements. These factors influence wind turbulence and create directional dependencies, complicating the estimation of z0m for remote sensing models and land surface models.

Causal Consequence.Question: What consequences might arise from applying Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory (MOST) to Large Aperture Scintillometer data in varied geographical locations?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Applying MOST to LAS data across different geographical locations may lead to challenges due to varying surface types and meteorological conditions which can affect the theory's applicability. Adjustments may be necessary to account for factors such as surface heterogeneity, atmospheric stability, and turbulence, which can influence the accuracy and reliability of the derived flux measurements. This requires developing and validating quantitative judgment methods for MOST applicability in diverse settings.

Causal Consequence.Question: If footprint models are used to aggregate aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) across heterogeneous surfaces, what impact does this have on the parameterization of z0m for remote sensing models?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using footprint models to aggregate z0m across heterogeneous surfaces can provide a more representative parameterization of z0m for remote sensing models. This is because it accounts for the direction-dependent nature of z0m due to the spatial distribution of surface roughness elements. Such parameterization can improve the accuracy of remote sensing algorithms and land surface models by offering a more precise estimation of surface roughness characteristics, thus enhancing model outputs for varied applications.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the primary objectives of collecting multi-scale surface flux observations using eddy-covariance systems with meteorological elements in regions like the Haihe River Basin?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objectives include estimating surface fluxes accurately with remote sensing algorithms or land surface models, understanding the exchange intensity of heat and water vapor between the land and atmosphere, and studying the energy balance and water cycle processes at varying spatial scales. Eddy-covariance systems, being internationally recognized as reliable for small-scale observations, provide crucial data for these purposes.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the intended outcomes of parameterizing aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) in relation to land surface properties for remote sensing and land surface modeling?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The intended outcomes are to provide a heuristic parameterization of z0m that can be used as a reference in model parameterizations, thus facilitating the estimation of surface fluxes over heterogeneous landscapes. By relating z0m to land surface properties such as vegetation height and leaf area index, researchers aim to improve the accuracy and applicability of remote sensing algorithms and land surface models at local and regional scales.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How do researchers determine and handle the challenges of applying Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory in large aperture scintillometer (LAS) data analysis?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Researchers handle the challenges of applying Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory in LAS data analysis by analyzing the influence of surface cover types, flatness, water-heat conditions, and weather conditions on the theory's applicability. They propose new methods, such as factor analysis and the temperature structure parameter method, to quantitatively assess and verify the applicability of the theory under different atmospheric conditions.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methodologies are employed to ensure the accurate calculation of aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) over heterogeneous surfaces, and how is this parameter integrated into larger-scale models?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To accurately calculate aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) over heterogeneous surfaces, methodologies involve using an analytical footprint model and aggregating individual z0m values from various surface components based on roughness element characteristics like vegetation height and leaf area index. These values are then aggregated using a footprint weighting method, providing a heuristic parameterization of z0m that can be used as a reference in model parameterizations for remote sensing and land surface models.

Enablement.Question: What conditions must be met to enable Large Aperture Scintillometer (LAS) systems to effectively measure regional-scale surface fluxes?
Enablement.Answer: For LAS systems to effectively measure regional-scale surface fluxes, conditions such as an appropriate alignment of the instruments over large distances (hundreds of meters to kilometers) and the matching of their measurement scales with satellite pixel scales must be met. Additionally, the Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory needs to be applicable, and the area should ideally have homogeneous surface conditions or be carefully analyzed for heterogeneity impacts.

Expectation.Question: Why might it be challenging to accurately parameterize aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) across different land surfaces using existing datasets?
Expectation.Answer: Accurate parameterization of aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) across different land surfaces might be challenging due to the large variation in z0m observed over different surfaces, ranging from urban to smooth water bodies. This variation is influenced by the structure and spacing of roughness elements, such as vegetation height and leaf area index, which are not uniformly distributed. Additionally, obtaining z0m at a local or regional scale using station observations alone is difficult, making it challenging to apply remote sensing models and land surface models accurately.

Expectation.Question: What are some of the expectations when utilizing large aperture scintillometer (LAS) data for regional scale flux measurements, and why might these expectations not be met?
Expectation.Answer: The expectation when utilizing large aperture scintillometer (LAS) data for regional scale flux measurements is that it can provide average sensible heat flux values over larger areas, matching satellite pixel scales and numerical weather prediction model grid scales. However, these expectations might not be met due to limitations in the Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory (MOST), especially under unstable conditions where large-scale eddy movements and atmospheric turbulence development can affect its applicability. Moreover, the lack of agreement on the universal stability function and challenges with low wind speed and very stable conditions can impact the convergence of calculations.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how data quality is evaluated and ensured in surface flux measurements using eddy covariance systems.
Assertion.Answer: Data quality in surface flux measurements using eddy covariance systems is evaluated through quality assessment metrics such as atmospheric stability (Δst) and turbulence similarity characteristics (ITC). The data undergo post-processing steps like coordinate rotation, frequency response correction, and density corrections to ensure accuracy. Specific criteria are applied to filter out unreliable data, such as excluding data during instrument errors, precipitation, and when turbulence is weak.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of how aerodynamic roughness length is calculated over different land surfaces and its significance in remote sensing models.
Assertion.Answer: Aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) is calculated using wind profile measurements based on the Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory. Its significance in remote sensing models and land surface models lies in its ability to describe the roughness characteristics of a surface, which is crucial for surface flux estimations. Researchers have developed parameterizations to estimate z0m based on land surface properties like vegetation height and leaf area index, due to its large variation over different surfaces.

Assertion.Question: I’m unsure why large aperture scintillometer (LAS) is preferred for regional scale flux measurements compared to traditional methods.
Assertion.Answer: Large aperture scintillometer (LAS) is preferred for regional scale flux measurements because it can cover larger areas (from hundreds of meters to several kilometers) compared to traditional methods like the eddy covariance system, which covers smaller spatial scales. The LAS data can be better aligned with satellite pixel scales and numerical weather model grid scales, making it suitable for validating and optimizing remote sensing models and numerical weather predictions.

Request/Directive.Question: Please provide an overview of the challenges faced in ensuring data quality and consistency in surface flux measurements across different observation stations and methods.
Request/Directive.Answer: Challenges in data quality and consistency arise from variations in land surface types, meteorological conditions, and the scale of observation. For instance, EC system observations can suffer from energy imbalance issues, while LAS measurements may face difficulties in stable atmospheric conditions or low wind speeds. Ensuring consistent application of Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory (MOST) and addressing variations due to roughness element characteristics are essential for data quality.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore potential sources or strategies for collecting additional datasets to enhance the understanding of aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) across different land surfaces.
Request/Directive.Answer: To enhance understanding of z0m, it is beneficial to collect additional datasets that include characteristic parameters of roughness elements, such as vegetation height and leaf area index. Utilizing an analytical footprint model can help analyze directional characteristics of z0m over heterogeneous surfaces. Parameterizations between z0m and land surface properties, as proposed by former researchers, can also aid in scaling up observations for remote sensing and land surface models.
